Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention;
Title prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
Description (e) Restraining youth in a prone position or any restraint
that restricts the youth’s airway.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was restrained in a prone position.
Investigation Youth B was interviewed on 02/08/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit at the facility. Youth B recalled witnessing an
incident where Youth A was restrained face down on the ground
for a “long time.” Youth B believed this occurred prior to
Thanksgiving the year before. Youth B did not recall any other
details from the alleged incident. This investigation was initiated
by DCWL because of this interview.
Youth A was interviewed by Consultant 2 at his current placement
during an announced, face-to-face visit on 03/05/2024. Youth A
stated he recalled the incident at the facility, but also stated he
has anxiety and blacked out during parts of the incident. Youth A
stated he told Staff 6 he was going outside to walk around the
house. Youth A stated he banged on the locked door when he
could not re-enter. Youth A stated he sat down to watch television
but had thoughts of beating Staff 6. Youth A stated he told Staff 6,
“I should hate you, but my dad said not to hit females.” Youth A
stated he got up and went back outside and walked around
campus. Youth A stated Staff 3, Staff 6, and Staff 7 followed him
around campus causing more anger. Youth A stated he thought
about breaking Staff 6’s car window with a log he found. Youth A
stated instead he headed back to the house to talk with another
youth, but Staff 3 blocked the door to the house. Youth A stated
he became mad and ran around the house with the log. Youth A
stated Staff 5 tried to grab the log from him when they were by a
window. Youth A stated he hit Staff 5 in the face. Youth A stated
his anxiety increased and Staff 3 and Staff 5 restrained him to the
ground on his stomach. Youth A stated it felt like he was on the
ground for an hour eating dirt before staff tried to get him up on his
knees. Youth A stated he tried to move out of the hold and was
placed back on the ground on his stomach. Youth A stated Staff 6
and Staff 2 held his legs and Staff 3 and Staff 5 secured his arms.
2

Youth A stated someone was on his back but did not know who.
Youth A stated he was crying and did commit to go back to the
house. Youth A stated he wanted a shower. Youth A stated he
started throwing papers and things in his room and Staff 3 and
Staff 5 blocked his door and restrained him to the ground on his
stomach. Youth A stated he hit his head on his desk and on the
floor in this restraint. Youth A said Staff 5 and Staff 3 secured his
arms and Staff 2 and Staff 6 secured his legs. Youth A stated he
kicked someone but does not know who. Youth A stated the police
came and he went to the hospital. Youth A was asked if he was
willing to review certain parts of the incident report and that he
could stop if the questions triggered him. Youth A agreed. Youth A
does not recall the other youth who might have witnessed the
incident. Youth A stated he grabbed Youth C by the collar and
shoved Youth C to the wall and staff separated them. Youth A
said he tried to climb onto the school’s roof. Youth A denied trying
to break into cars. Youth A said Staff 5’s car was unlocked, and he
sat in the car and got out. Youth A stated he did spit in Staff 8’s
face. He recalled that she assisted in restraining him inside the
house but did not recall details. Youth A did not recall Staff 4
being involved in the incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 03/12/2024. She
recalled being involved in most of the incident that occurred with
Youth A. Staff 1 stated Youth A was escalated and moved all
over campus for some time, attempting to break things and
screaming at himself and staff. Staff 1 recalled him stating threats
of self-harm and physical harm to any staff that was near him.
Staff 1 recalled the first attempt at restraining Youth A occurring
after he punched Staff 5. At that point Staff 1 recalled Staff 5
attempting a standing one-person restraint of Youth A, only for this
to quickly devolve when Youth A fought back at Staff 5. Staff 1
stated she could not recall exactly what happened next other than
Youth A was fighting often and staff that were involved with him,
fell to the ground with him. Staff 1 could not recall exactly who
was involved. Staff 1 was positive that Youth A going to the
ground was accidental. She could not recall if he fell on his side
or face down first but recalled he was on his stomach face down
for some amount of time. Staff 1 believed Youth A did not have
any trouble breathing because he was consistently vocal and did
not say anything about struggling to breath or being in pain. She
did recall Youth A hitting his knee on the way down. Staff 1
believed the other staff involved at this point were Staff 2, Staff 4
and Staff 7. Staff 1 could not recall how long this part of the
incident lasted but stated she was also involved with Youth A
when he had to be restrained later in the evening. Staff 1 stated
3

that this occurred inside of his bedroom. She recalled him
punching doors and walls and that staff were afraid that he would
hurt himself. Staff 1 could not recall who initiated restraint efforts
but believed that this began with a one person standing restraint
that was not able to be successful when Youth A fell to the
ground, taking staff with him. At this point Youth A was biting and
kicking anyone that was near him. Staff 1 did not believe Youth A
struggled to breath or had any pain during this part of the restraint.
She stated he was on his chest on the floor of his room and this
restraint lasted until law enforcement arrived. Law enforcement
then was able to speak with Youth A to attempt to de-escalate the
assaultive and destructive behavior.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 03/12/2024. She
stated she does not work at the facility anymore but recalled the
incident in question. Staff 2 recalled the first instance of needing
to restrain Youth A was when he was outside of one of the units
and had been destructive and assaultive for some time leading up
to that point. She believed Staff 3 and Staff 5 had to try to start
the restraint while Youth A was standing, when Youth A dropped
to the ground and took the staff members with him. Staff 2
recalled Youth A hitting Staff 5 in the face during this portion of the
incident. Staff 2 stated Youth A fell on his stomach with his face
to the side. She stated none of the staff involved, including
herself, attempted to pick up Youth A so he would not be in a
prone position, nor did they disengage. Staff 2 recalled
disengaging was difficult because Youth A was attempting to hit
anyone he could, and he had a rock in his hand that he was trying
to throw at a nearby building. Staff 2 could not recall how that
restraint attempt ended. She stated she was involved in the
second restraint effort as well. Staff 2 believed this effort was not
as warranted as outside; in that it was “hurting him more than it
was calming him down.” She recalled his room being in disarray
after he had caused some property destruction. Staff 2 stated
there were already staff members holding Youth A’s shoulders
when she came into the room to assist with holding his legs. She
believed Staff 5 and Staff 4 were holding his shoulders. Staff 2
confirmed Youth A was lying face down for this part of the
restraint. Staff 2 believed Staff 5 was laying somewhat on top of
Youth A. At this point Youth A was biting and kicking anyone near
him. Staff 2 stated staff attempted to disengage at one point, but
Staff 5 had hands on Youth A still through this portion of the
restraint. Staff 2 recalled being told by other staff, that she could
not recall, that they were to hold Youth A on the ground until law
enforcement arrived. Staff 2 stated Youth A’s energy eventually
calmed down. Staff 2 believed it was Staff 3 that was in
4

communication with Supervisor 1, who had given the direction to
not let Youth A go for fear of more destructive and assaultive
behavior towards staff. Staff 2 also recalled not feeling like she
was trained well in attempting a restraint like this. She recalled
her restraint training to only exist of role-playing standing holds,
and they were always taught to never restrain a youth on the
ground in any form.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 03/15/2024. He
recalled being a part of the escalated incident with Youth A on
09/28/2023. Staff 3 stated there were hours of activity prior to
restraints occurring with Youth A that day, including staff providing
line of sight and managing the environment for him as he moved
all over campus and attempted to destroy property and assault
staff. Staff 3 stated he could not remember details of the first
restraint attempts when Youth A was still outside. He believed
that the first attempt at restraining Youth A was when a staff
member, he could not remember who, attempted a standing
restraint, but Youth A took them both to the ground. Staff 3 stated
Youth A was on his stomach at this point and did not immediately
get up because the staff involved did not let go immediately. Staff
3 never heard Youth A state he was having trouble breathing in
any form, or that he was in pain. Staff 3 only recalled Youth A
continued with threatening and aggressive statements throughout
the restraint episode. Staff 3 could not recall exactly how the
restraint ended but did recall Youth A ended up inside. Staff 3
was not involved in the second instance of restraining Youth A
inside because he was outside the unit waiting for law
enforcement to arrive.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone on 03/18/2024. She
recalled the incident in question. Staff 4 stated she did not
primarily work in the same unit as Youth A but was called over for
assistance when the restraint began outside of his unit. She
recalled Youth A throwing punches at staff and threatening them,
as well as making self-harm statements. She could not recall
exactly which staff were also involved, but she stated the first
thing she saw was staff attempting a standing restraint of Youth A.
She recalled seeing Youth A drop his weight to the ground, taking
staff to the ground with him. Staff 4 stated Youth A was then
laying on his stomach for a short amount of time before he got up
on his own power when he committed to safety. Staff 4 stated
sometime later, Youth A slammed his bedroom door and was
presumably destroying property in his room, as well as attempting
to barricade himself in there. Staff 4 stated another staff member
that she could not recall, was able to gain access to the room.
5

This was attempted because there is a policy against closed
bedroom doors and there was active concern for Youth A
attempting to harm himself if not supervised and possibly
intervened with. Staff 4 recalled Youth A throwing punches
towards staff at this point and another standing restraint was
attempted, only for Youth A and the staff involved to fall to the
floor again. Staff 4 stated she was trained in never performing
restraints when youth were on the ground, but it was decided in
this instance to perform an “emergency floor restraint” because of
the severity of Youth A’s aggressive behaviors. As an example of
behavior, Staff 4 stated she was bit by Youth A during this
physical escalation. Staff 4 recalled Youth A was on his stomach
during this portion of the restraint. She was not sure when he de-
escalated overall other than several attempts by staff to disengage
with Youth A, only for him to immediately destroy property or try to
assault staff which caused them to re-engage while he was on the
floor.
Documents reviewed:
• Because of the extended time since the incident occurred,
video footage was not able to be produced by the facility.
• An Incident Report authored on 09/29/2023 regarding the
09/28/2023 incident involving Youth A was provided. In this
documentation there is narrative describing significantly
escalated, assaultive and destructive behavior on the part
of Youth A. The beginning of the documentation refers to
approximately 7:05 pm as when Youth A began to
escalate. This all described the staff’s reasoning for
attempting to restrain Youth A on two different occasions,
once outside at approximately 8:45 pm and then again
inside at 10:10 pm. Law enforcement arrived and were
able to transport Youth A to the hospital for medical
attention related to his suicidal comments.
• Facility policy titled “Prevention Techniques for Overnight
Staff” was provided and reviewed. In this policy it stated for
staff to “make sure that all bedroom doors are wide open
(students are NOT permitted to close bedroom doors).”
• Facility policy titled “NVCI Training for Physical
Intervention” was reviewed. The facility utilizes the
approved Non-Violent Crisis Intervention restraint
model. In this policy it was described that:
o “In the event that a restraint ends up on the floor due
to the student struggling the staff have the following
options:
1. Disengage the youth. If the youth is still
exhibiting dangerous behaviors and meets
6

the criteria for physical management, staff
are able to renegade the student once he
stands up.
2. Help bring the student back up to his knees
or a standing position. This needs to be
done without the use of force i.e. dragging or
pulling the student to one of these positions).
3. If a student begins to struggle while in an
escort or team control, staff can utilize one of
the escort positions that allow for the student
to be in a seated position.
4. In extenuating circumstances students may
be transitioned to a supine position per the
NVCI advanced skills. This should only be
used in situations where the first three
options are not viable and safety issues
necessitate this move.”
o The restraint policy provides descriptions for three
restraint holds:
▪ Team Control Position as a standing restraint
involving two staff members standing at the
side of a youth, holding the youth’s shoulders
from the back and extending the youths arms
across their bodies and holding at the wrist.
▪ Emergency Floor Holding - Supine as a
restraint where a youth is laying on their back
on the ground, and three staff hold their
shoulders and arms respectively.
▪ Emergency Floor Holding - Supported Prone
as a restraint where a youth is laying on their
front on the ground and three staff hold their
shoulders and arms respectively.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed there was evidence found to show that Youth A was
restrained in a prone position during two different parts of the
escalated incident that occurred on 09/28/2023 and staff did not
immediately disengage.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to update their restraint training
materials and policy to eliminate any positions or mentions
of a youth in a prone position on the ground. In addition,
review and editing of restraint training should occur to
clarify what kinds of restraint efforts would be approved for
youth on the ground in a supine position so that staff are
7

confident in the moment when they need to attempt to
perform this restraint.
• The facility is advised to focus training on their chosen
restraint model to ensure that rule 400.4159 (6) is met even
during the most escalated incidents, allowing youth to be
restrained only for the minimal time needed for the youth to
calm down and restore safety.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2023C0000338 approved 05/02/2023. CAP approved
05/22/2023.
Rule Code Health status assessment; notification; debriefing; reporting.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4163
Section (5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form
Description prescribed by the department for each incident involving
the use of seclusion or restraint. The initial report shall be
submitted to the department within 24 hours of the
incident occurring. A final incident report shall be
submitted no later than 72 hours after the incident has
occurred.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Documentation for this incident was inaccurate.
Investigation There were consistent recollections in all interviews with youth
and staff for this investigation of Youth A being on the ground on
two separate points in time during the 09/28/2023 incident. All
individuals interviewed recalled Youth A being on his stomach in a
prone position without staff immediately disengaging or Youth A
getting up from the ground.
Documents reviewed:
• In the Incident Report authored on 09/29/2023 that
described the 09/28/2023 incident with Youth A, multiple
restraint attempts are described. The only technical term
used to describe these attempts was Youth A was put in
the Team Control Position multiple times, and on each
attempt the restraint attempts fell to the ground. Staff
attempted to disengage and verbally de-escalate Youth A
at the same time. It is not stated in any part of the Incident
Report that Youth A was ever in a prone position during
these restraint attempts that went to the ground.
8

Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff and documentation
reviewed there was evidence to find the Incident Report written for
the 09/28/2023 incident involving Youth A did not contain accurate
information.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Based on the findings in this report a CAP is required.
Per SIR # 2024C0000983SI, a 1st provisional license is recommended.
